Award.AwardTitle: Acquisition of a laser-ablation system for trace element mapping and large-N geochronology by inductively-coupled-plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding for a laser to connect to an existing device at Johns Hopkins University that measures chemical compositions of samples. The laser system will support creative Geosciences research on tiny samples that contain information about the formation of the Earth. The laser will help to start new research partnerships among early-career Geoscientists from universities in the Baltimore area. This research will support numerous graduate and undergraduate students. The laser system will be included in undergraduate courses at many Baltimore-area universities. It will bring advanced technology and ideas to young minds and broaden their exposure to modern research and instrumentation in the geosciences.

A laser ablation (LA) system is requested to link to an existing triple-quadrupole inductively-coupled-plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) at Johns Hopkins University. The LA system will enable high-spatial-resolution, in situ analysis of geomaterials. The Hopkins LA-ICP-MS Facility will focus on fine-scale trace element mapping, and large-N U/Pb geochronology. It will also offer capacity for very sensitive trace and rare earth element analysis of solid samples. An updated Hopkins LA-ICP-MS Facility is important for the research programs of multiple early-career geoscientists based in the Baltimore area, and will serve the broader Mid-Atlantic region. Existing projects proposed to utilize the Hopkins LA-ICP-MS Facility span multiple disciplines, from the biogeosciences to meteoritics, petrology, plate tectonics and archaeology. The Hopkins LA-ICP-MS Facility will offer graduate and undergraduate research students valuable training in modern geosciences research and will be incorporated into undergraduate courses at multiple universities in the Baltimore area.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major outcome of the award was purchase, receipt and establishment of a laser ablation (LA) system to couple to an existing inductively-coupled-plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) at Johns Hopkins University (JHU). The new LA-ICP-MS facility at JHU offers modern, high-performance analytical capability that will enable various new avenues of geosciences research in the Baltimore area; upcoming projects will address research topics from 'investigating drivers of plate tectonic rearrangements' to 'probing events leading to the rise of complex life', and 'understanding the emergence of socio-economic complexity through records of geomaterials trade'. Though the facility was designed and funded for geosciences research, benefits are not restricted to the geosciences; recent 'alternative' uses of the new facility include work for Baltimore-based research projects on the development of crystalline materials for high-energy-laser technologies and nanomaterials for quantum applications.

 

Impacts of the new LA-ICP-MS facility at JHU extend beyond scientific results, including training and upskilling of multiple undergraduate researchers, graduate students and postdoctoral researchers from local-area research institutions, including JHU, Towson University and the Smithsonian Institution. Such training will lead to the students and researchers each taking their experience in and knowledge of LA-ICP-MS on to future study/positions/careers. Furthermore, starting 2020, Baltimore-area High School Students placed in the Department of Earth & Planetary Sciences, JHU by JHU's Women in Science & Engineering (WISE) program and/or the Baltimore Ingenuity Project will be offered extended opportunities to learn about and use the LA-ICP-MS in their own research internship projects. These education and outreach activities extend the impact of the new LA-ICP-MS beyond simply 'data produced'.
